title: Allow users to add custom icons for integrated terminals

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: Description Feature Request Currently, Visual Studio Code allows customization of terminal profiles (name, path, color, etc.), but does not support adding custom icons for each terminal. This makes it harder to visually distinguish multiple terminals when working with different environments (e.g., Node.js, Python, Docker, remote SSH). And recently, with the development of AI CLI such as Gemini CLI and Claude Code, it's more important to distinguish them by terminal icon. Claude Code has already used their own icon in integrated terminal. But I found available icons are less. I hope we could allow users to add custom icons from sites like:https://simpleicons.org/?q=gemini Motivation • Improves usability when multiple terminal profiles are open but screen space is limited. • Provides a quick visual cue to identify which terminal corresponds to which runtime or task. • Consistent with the customization options available for activity bar and file icons. Proposed Solution • Extend terminal profile configuration in settings.json to include an optional icon field. • Support both built-in VSCode icons (Codicons) and user-provided custom icons (SVG/PNG). • Display the icon alongside the terminal name in the dropdown and tab bar.

title: Allow Copilot Sessions to Continue After Declining Suggested Actions and capture refusal reasons
body: ### Problem Currently, when a user declines an action that Copilot suggests (such as running a database migration or deleting files), the session ends immediately. This abrupt ending can disrupt workflow and user experience. ### Expected Behavior When a user declines a suggested action, Copilot should simply acknowledge the user's choice and continue working on the problem. The session should not end unless the user explicitly chooses to cancel or stop it. Additionally, users should have the option to specify the reason for refusing an action. This could help Copilot better understand user preferences, improve suggestions, and potentially offer better alternatives. ### Example Scenario - Copilot suggests running a database migration. - The user declines the action. - Instead of ending the session, Copilot acknowledges the choice and continues working, skipping that step or finding alternatives. ### Benefit This change would provide a smoother and less disruptive user experience, allowing users to continue working without interruption after declining specific actions.

title: User-in-the-loop Model Guidance via User Suggestions Scratchpad
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## Problem
Currently, when a model encounters a challenging problem, it may spend unnecessary time exploring solutions, even when the developer has potential ideas or directions in mind.

## Proposed Solution
Introduce a "User Suggestions" scratchpad—a dedicated space (such as a file) where developers can jot down ideas, directions, or approaches for the model to periodically review. This helps streamline the problem-solving process by allowing the model to consider developer insights.

### Alternative Approaches for Reviewing Suggestions
1. **Event-Driven Approach:** The model listens for events (such as file changes or explicit user actions) and reviews suggestions when notified.
2. **Integrated Suggestion API/Endpoint:** Provide an endpoint for suggestions, so the model fetches new input at key workflow steps.
3. **UI-Driven Suggestions:** Integrate suggestion input directly in the developer’s IDE or via a web dashboard, prompting review at relevant moments.
4. **Conversation-Based Suggestions:** Allow suggestions via chat or issue comments, with the model parsing and considering them dynamically.
5. **Suggestions Queue with Notifications:** Store suggestions in a queue and notify the model when new items arrive for prioritized review.
6. **“Review User Suggestions” Step During Retrospectives:** Add a dedicated step to the model’s workflow where, during retrospectives, it reviews all user suggestions before proceeding. This ensures suggestions are considered systematically and transparently.

## Suggested Implementation
- Create a scratchpad file for user suggestions.
- The model should check this file at regular intervals (or use one of the alternative approaches above).
- The model is not required to follow the suggestions unless explicitly instructed.
- If the model chooses to ignore a suggestion, it should briefly explain why (in a single line).

## Benefits
- Enables more effective collaboration between developers and models.
- Reduces time spent on unproductive exploration.
- Provides transparency when model decisions differ from developer suggestions.

title: Group Conversations with Git Branch Context in Copilot Chat

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

**Summary:**
Introduce the ability to create and manage grouped conversations in GitHub Copilot Chat, with the option to associate each group with a specific branch of the current repository.

**Detailed Description:**
When working on a project with multiple concurrent features, it’s common to switch between branches frequently. Each branch often represents a distinct context - like a new feature, bug fix, or refactor, and ideally, conversations with Copilot should reflect that.

This feature would allow developers to:

* **Create and name conversation groups** within Copilot Chat.
* **Associate each group with a specific Git branch** in the current VS Code workspace.
* **Automatically switch Copilot chat context** when switching between branches.
* View and resume prior conversations relevant to a branch, maintaining continuity in problem-solving and discussions.

**Use Case:**
Imagine I'm working on three different features:

* `feature/login-auth`
* `feature/payment-integration`
* `bugfix/navbar-glitch`

Each of these branches has different technical needs, issues, and ongoing conversations with Copilot. Instead of one long, cluttered history, I’d like to keep conversations grouped by their corresponding branch. That way, when I switch from `feature/login-auth` to `bugfix/navbar-glitch`, I immediately get back the relevant chat history and context - questions I asked, Copilot’s suggestions, and code snippets - all tied to that specific line of work.

**Benefits:**

* Cleaner, more organized Copilot chat experience.
* Context-aware conversations.
* Increased productivity and focus when juggling multiple branches/features.
* Easier collaboration: when teammates check out a branch, they can access the related conversation history for that branch as well (if shared).

title: Select and move parts of conversation to a new chat to reduce context bloat
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

### Problem

When working in long conversations, it is often desirable to select only specific segments (typically the most recent messages) and move them into a new chat. This helps minimize unnecessary context bloat and keeps interactions relevant and focused.

### Proposed Solution

Add a feature that enables users to select portions of an existing conversation and start a new chat with only those selected messages. This would allow users to effectively 'edit' the conversation state, without impacting any files or actions that have already been performed in previous messages.

### Key Points
- Ability to select specific messages (e.g., last few) from a chat
- Move selected messages into a new chat instance
- Ensure previously modified files and actions remain unaffected
- Improves context management and user experience

### Motivation
This feature would greatly simplify workflows in cases where conversations become too lengthy or contain irrelevant context, allowing users to focus only on the essential parts of the chat.

title: **VS Code agent (e.g., Copilot Agent) always uses the same terminal for server and e2e commands, causing server interruption**
body:
Type: Bug ### Title **VS Code agent (e.g., Copilot Agent) always uses the same terminal for server and e2e commands, causing server interruption** --- ### Description When prompting the agent to run a development server and end-to-end (e2e) tests, it reuses the same terminal. This interrupts the server when the test command runs, instead of launching each command in a separate terminal context. --- ### Steps to Reproduce 1. In VS Code, open a workspace with: * A development server script, e.g. `npm run dev` * An e2e test script, e.g. `npm run test:e2e` 2. Prompt the Copilot or Agent to: * First, open a new terminal and run the server (`npm run dev`) * Then, in another prompt, open a new terminal and run e2e tests (`npm run test:e2e`) 3. Observe that both commands execute in the *same terminal*, causing the server to stop when running the e2e tests. --- ### Expected Behavior Each command runs in its own distinct terminal. The server should remain running while the tests execute in a separate terminal. --- ### Actual Behavior Both commands run in the **same terminal** by default, leading to the server being interrupted when the agent runs the test command. There's no explicit terminal control unless manually prefaced with commands like `workbench.action.terminal.new`, and even then, the behavior may be inconsistent. --- ### Reproducibility Consistently reproducible under the following conditions: * VS Code version: e.g., **1.80.0-insider** (please specify the exact version) * Agent: using Copilot Chat or an OSVS (OpenAI or custom) agent * Workspace containing server and e2e commands --- ### Logs & Diagnostics Please attach the following when filing the issue: * **Output Channel logs** for both `Window` and `Copilot Chat` (set `Log Level` to `Trace`) * Any error messages from the Output panel * Screenshots or screen recordings showing: * Agent prompts * Terminal behavior (same vs. separate terminals) * **Language model request logs** from `Developer: Open Chat Debug View`, specifically showing: * The agent instructions given * Any internal logs for injecting `workbench.action.terminal.new` * Network diagnostics, if relevant `[Developer: GitHub Copilot Chat Diagnostics]` --- ### Agent Instructions Example You may include the exact phrasing you used. For example: ``` First: run VS Code command "workbench.action.terminal.new". Then: in that terminal run `npm run dev`. Then again: First: run VS Code command "workbench.action.terminal.new". Then: in that terminal run `npm run test:e2e`. ``` --- ### Additional Context * Agent should support running tasks in **dedicated terminals** by default, not just manual or conventially phrased commands. * Without proper terminal handling, long-lived processes like local servers get terminated unexpectedly. * In complex workflows (e.g., development server + tests), this disrupts automation and development flow. - OS Version: Windows 11

- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude Sonnet 3.5):

Steps to Reproduce (Copied from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release/issues/9051, because it is the same issue):

    Manually modify parts of copilot's changes
    Ask copilot for another incremental change

=> Now copilot reapplies changes from 1. that I changed in 2. because I want it to be solved differently. This happens pretty often and makes it annoying to iterate with copilot.

title: [iPadOS] Cannot select text in GitHub Codespaces editor (Safari/Chrome)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: touch/pointer
labels.description: Touch and Pointer Device support related issues

body: - VS Code Version: GitHub Codespaces (VS Code Web) - OS Version: iPadOS 18.6x - Device: iPad ( model, e.g., iPad 9th Gen / iPad Pro M1) - Browsers Tested: Safari (latest), Chrome (latest) ### Issues 1. **Text Selection Not Working** - Double tap on a word does not select it. - Long press + drag does not highlight text consistently. - Works fine on desktop browsers. 2. **On-Screen Keyboard Issue** - When I tap inside a file editor, the iPad on-screen keyboard does **not appear**. - The keyboard only shows up after I tap into the **terminal** first. - After that, I can edit the file normally. ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open GitHub Codespace on iPad (Safari or Chrome). 2. Open a file (e.g., .py or .js). 3. Try to select text (double tap or drag) → fails. 4. Try to type in file editor → no keyboard appears. 5. Tap inside terminal → keyboard appears. 6. Go back to file → now typing works. ### Expected Behavior - Text selection (double tap, drag) should work like on desktop. - On-screen keyboard should appear immediately when tapping inside the editor. ### Actual Behavior - Text selection fails. - Keyboard does not appear until terminal is tapped. ### Notes - Happens even with all extensions disabled. - Likely an issue with touch + input handling in VS Code Web on iPadOS. - Screenshots attached.

Nothing.

title: Kernel Trap in code[623ee0903000+8def000]
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:
  `1.103.1 360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da x64`
   Installed from original deb-package:
```deb-src
Package: code
Version: 1.103.1-1755017277
APT-Sources: https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/code stable/main amd64 Packages
```

- OS Version:
  `Ubuntu 24.04.3 LTS noble` 
  `Linux 6.8.0-71-generic (x86_64)`
  `Gnome 46 (Wayland)`
  
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Starting from desktop icon or command-line results doesn't seem to do anything (no error  message or any other output). But system journal shows the following:
```log
Aug 16 15:44:23 myhost kernel: \
  traps: code[250415] trap int3 ip:625d95b123c3 sp:77d5b3ed1a20 \
  error:0 in code[625d915a4000+8def000]`
```

With the part `code[625d915a4000+8def000]` alawys remaining consistent.

2. Multiple re-installs, de-installs, removing apt-source and re-downloading the original deb-package, etc. didn't help.

3. Tried multiple ways on command-line. Kernel trap remains consistent: E.g. 
```bash
ELECTRON_RUN_AS_NODE=1 /usr/share/code/bin/code \
          /usr/share/code/resources/app/out/cli.js \
          --verbose \
          --disable-extensions --disable-gpu --disable-chromium-sandbox
```

The lengthy output from the `--verbose` option doesn't show anything suspicious (at least not to me).

title: VS Code crashes when using Copilot chat
body: # VS Code crashes consistently when using Copilot chat for the second time Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes** - VS Code Version: 1.103.1 - OS Version: Windows 11 24H2 26100.4946 ## Steps to Reproduce: 1. Log in to GitHub Pro account 2. Enable GitHub Copilot 3. Open a new VS Code window 4. Use Copilot chat for the first time (works normally) 5. Try to input a second message in Copilot chat 6. VS Code crashes immediately ## Expected Behavior: Copilot chat should continue working normally for subsequent inputs without crashing VS Code. ## Actual Behavior: VS Code crashes with the following error after the second Copilot chat input: **Error Message (Chinese):** ``` 窗口意外终止(原因: "crashed", 代码: "-2147483645") 我们对此不便表示道歉! 请重启该窗口以从上次停止的位置继续。 ``` **Error Translation:** ``` Window unexpectedly terminated (Reason: "crashed", Code: "-2147483645") We apologize for this inconvenience! Please restart the window to continue from where it was last stopped. ``` ## Additional Information: - This crash occurs consistently and reproducibly - The first Copilot chat interaction works fine - The crash happens immediately upon entering the second input - Issue persists even with all extensions disabled - Error code: -2147483645 ## Troubleshooting Already Attempted: - ✅ Disabled all extensions (`code --disable-extensions`) - ✅ Issue still occurs with clean extension state --- *Note: As my native language is Chinese, I used Claude AI to help compose this issue report in English to ensure clarity and proper formatting.*

title: Allow Language Model Tools to leverage images
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When trying to build an extension that uses LanguageModelTools to add images as context to Chat, I ran into limitations with the way images are handled.

My suggestion is adding a `vscode.LanguageModelImagePart` to allow tools to returns images as results,
**or** alternatively exposing a read image tool that can be invoked separately which will read files saved by tools.

Type: Bug ```markdown # GitHub Copilot Issue Report: Tensor Shape Misinterpretation ## Description Copilot inconsistently interprets square brackets as: - Tensor shapes for `x`, `edge_index` (correct) - Literal values for `y` (incorrect) ## Steps to Reproduce ```python data = [ DataBatch(x=[876, 128], edge_index=[2, 1117], y=[2], batch=[876], ptr=[3]), DataBatch(x=[506, 128], edge_index=[2, 696], y=[2], batch=[506], ptr=[3]) ] ``` ## Expected Behavior ```python # All square brackets should be shapes: x=[876, 128] → torch.Size([876, 128]) edge_index=[2,696] → torch.Size([2, 696]) y=[2] → torch.Size([2]) # Actual content: tensor([0, 1]) ``` ## Actual Behavior ```python # Correct: x=[876, 128] → torch.Size([876, 128]) # Incorrect: y=[2] → Literal integer `2` # Should be tensor shape ``` ## Environment - Copilot: VSCode Extension (Latest) - Pattern: 100% reproducible when `y=[N]` appears ``` Extension version: 0.30.1 VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes: Remote OS version: Linux x64 6.8.0-57-generic

VSCode exports the profile settings as "code-profile" file. This file is not human-readable. I can not make it human readable even with 3rd party formatters. Because most of information are stored as string.

Example part of file:

> "extensions": "[{\"identifier\":{\"id\":\"vscode.clojure\"},\"displayName\":\"Clojure Language Basics\",

In our company, we store default profiles for developers on Git repository (source control). So we can see the history of our configs. Like GitOps :)

Generally developers store their configs on a repository and they manage with dotfile-managers.

Is there any possibility to make the "code-profile" file JSON more human readable?

Thank you

title: Feature Request: Default to "Open File" instead of "Open File Snapshot" in chat when clicking on a modified file
body:
## Feature request
Make a single click on a modified file reference in the chat open the live, modified file. The context menu (right-click / secondary action) should continue to expose both **Open File** and **Open File Snapshot**.

## Problem
Currently the most direct interaction on a modified file reference does not give immediate access to the live file; users frequently want the live file with recent changes with one click. The existing behavior requires extra actions to reach the most common workflow, and clutters the tab bar.

## Proposed solution
- Single left-click on a modified file reference opens the live, modified file (the full file).
- Right-click / context menu (or equivalent secondary action) shows both **Open File** and **Open File Snapshot** so users can explicitly choose the snapshot/diff when they want it.

### Benefits
- One-click access to the file streamlines debugging and code review.
- Keeps snapshot/diff easily available without blocking the common flow.
- Reduces friction and unnecessary tab clutter caused by opening snapshots by default.

## Additional context
This is a UX/default interaction change only: snapshot functionality is preserved and explicitly available from the context menu.


![current-context-menu](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9c035a8e-108b-4769-b65d-dc3d82ade808)

<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 
- OS Version: 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. 
2.
[Expandable hovers for JavaScript and TypeScript](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_103#_expandable-hovers-for-javascript-and-typescript)

When you hover over a symbol in JavaScript or TypeScript, VS Code tries to show the most useful IntelliSense type information about that symbol. Types can be very complex, so one challenge for us has been trying to find the right balance between showing enough details to be useful, while not showing so much info that it becomes overwhelming. It's hard to come up with a good one size fits all approach, and also the level of type detail you want might change depending on what you are working on.

That's why this iteration, we've added new UI that gives you more control over how types are shown in hovers. When you hover over a symbol, now you can select the little + icon on the left side of the hover control to expand the interfaces and complex types in the hover into their components. For example, you can use this to see the properties of an interface directly in the hover:

Hovers can be expanded multiple times, which recursively expands types from the previous expansion. If you ever expand too much, just select the - icon to go back to the previous level. Also keep in mind that not every type is expandable and that we still need some limits on just how much expansion we can support. [Let us know](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=bug_report.md) if there are any cases where expandable hovers aren't working how you'd like

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The add-mcp CLI command, or the special link to add Mcp should support workspace installation, not only in the user profile.

This documentation says it is possible, but it is not: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/chat/mcp-servers#_commandline-configuration

References: https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/ai/mcp#mcp-url-handler

title: Termial bug
body: Type: Performance Issue Dear VS Code Team, I'm a new Python learner who recently reinstalled VS Code to begin my coding journey. While I’m excited to dive into development, I’ve been facing a persistent issue with file associations on Windows 11 — specifically, `.py` files are not consistently opening in VS Code, and Windows keeps prompting me to choose an app, even after setting VS Code as the default. As someone just starting out, this has been incredibly frustrating. I’ve tried multiple fixes including registry edits, default app settings, and command line tweaks, but the issue keeps recurring. It’s disheartening to hit such a technical roadblock so early in the learning process. I believe smoother integration between VS Code and Windows for Python files would make a huge difference for beginners like me. A more reliable way to register VS Code as the default handler for `.py` files — without pop-ups or manual workarounds — would be a welcome improvement. Thanks for all the amazing work you do. VS Code is an incredible tool, and I’m looking forward to growing with it as I learn Python. Best regards, WILLIAMS VS Code version: Code 1.103.1 (360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da, 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22621 Modes:

body:
Type: Bug i've saked how can i allow *some* shell commands ``` how can i allow you to run some shell commands without confirmation? like run builds, tests, read project files? ``` resp: `Let me run a fresh test to show you:` ``` it did not work, i'm using GitHub Copilot & Github Copilot Chat extensions in VSCode so it requires me to confirm every command to be run in terminal i understand the reason but there some commands seen to be safe to run without confirmation ``` resp: ``` What I can suggest for now: Since you mentioned wanting to run "safe" commands like builds and tests, when you see the confirmation dialog, you could: Click "Allow" for commands like: cargo build cargo test git status File reading operations ls, pwd, cat commands Be cautious with commands that: Modify files outside your project Install software Change system settings Access network resources Would you like me to help you look for any VS Code or GitHub Copilot settings that might control this behavior? ``` `yes that exactly what i need` resulted in changes to .vscode/settings.json ``` // GitHub Copilot Chat command execution settings "github.copilot.chat.allowCommandExecution": true, "github.copilot.chat.confirmBeforeExecution": false, "github.copilot.terminal.allowCommandExecution": true, // Trust settings for workspace commands "security.workspace.trust.enabled": true, "security.workspace.trust.untrustedFiles": "open", // Terminal settings "terminal.integrated.allowWorkspaceConfiguration": true, "terminal.integrated.confirmOnExit": "never" ``` there is unknown config settings but if they was known they seems to be less restrictive than ``` cargo build cargo test git status File reading operations ls, pwd, cat commands ``` not sure it should happen at all only explanation what parameters to change manually and where, and what consiquences it will have Extension version: 0.30.1 VS Code version: Code 1.103.1 (360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da, 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z) OS version: Linux x64 6.8.0-71-generic snap Modes:

body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please:

  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `main` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them.
-->
This adds a playwright based vscode developement MCP server to allow Agent mode the ability to _see_ the changes it's making.

The steps to use this should be simple:
* npm i
* Launch the `Launch MCP Server` task
* Start the server via the `mcp.json` in the workspace

There are some known issues:
1. clicking isn't working... this could be a bug in how I'm holding playwright, or there's a bug there
2. the browser is launched on initialize but really it should be launched, on first use of a real tool

title: Find and Search/Find in Files with selection from Terminal doesn't do regex escaping

labels.name: terminal-find
labels.description: Relating the terminal's find widget

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.1
- OS Version: Multiple

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable regex match mode in the Find in Files sidebar and the Find input in the Terminal
2. Highlight some text in the terminal including a regex special character, such as "foo(bar"
3. Press CTRL+F
4. Observe Find input shows "foo(bar" and has a warning "Invalid regular expression"
5. Highlight the same text in the terminal
6. Press CTRL+SHIFT+F
7. Observe Search sidebar top input shows "foo(bar" and has a warning "Invalid regular expression"
8. Repeat the steps above but making selections in the editor instead of the terminal
9. Observe the inputs are populated with "foo\\(bar", a valid regex matching the selected text.

The code that does regex escaping on the selection before populating the inputs isn't being run when the selection comes from the terminal instead of from the editor.

title: Serial Monitor Extension: Instructed to open the issue here (migrated from old repo)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Not applicable

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: Not applicable
- OS Version: Not applicable

---

Hi there, we have been having a problem with the **[Serial Monitor](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.vscode-serial-monitor)** extension for VS Code, which has been explained in detail [over here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-serial-monitor/issues/235#issuecomment-2804772008).

### The reason I am creating the issue over at VS Code repo is as follows:

When the previous repo was archived, @noiseonwires Instructed us to migrate any existing issues over to the **[Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/cpp)**.  If you visit the [Marketplace Page](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.vscode-serial-monitor) for the aforementioned extension, you can see that the **Issues** links also to that page.

With that in mind, I [created a topic over there](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Migrated-from-GitHub-VS-Codes-Serial/10946855?q=serial+monitor), explaining the issue.

However, user [Tina Schrepfer](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/user/1999) closed the topic, and then **instructed to create an issue over at this repo**:

> This is an issue affect Visual Studio Code, not Visual Studio. Please file a GitHub issue with the VS Code here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues. This feedback community is for Visual Studio product.

While I agree that the issue is neither related to **Visual Studio IDE**, nor **C++**, I am currently stuck in limbo as it's unclear where is the correct place to report and hopefully ask for a resolution for this issue, considering that the source code for this extension is not released, and doesn't have its own repo.

So, can you please ensure that the support links at the marketplace are pointing to the correct location (rather than the incorrect URL), and then help with resolving the bug I have linked above?

If this is yet again not the correct place to submit the issue, please explain where I might need to go next.

Thanks for the help! 🙏🏻

title: New "stripped-content" option for untitled tab names
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I have untitled tabs being named from the first line of the content. However, if I put a one-line description at the top, it causes a syntax error for whatever language is relevant (usually SQL), so I usually also add a comment marker (e.g. --).

I'd like an option (e.g. "stripped-content") that would strip leading and trailing non-word characters from the first line. This would allow a comment at the top to be used as the tab name (and default name for Save/Save As).

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
### **RUN MY APP button option**

...on the Copilot interface (potentially an airplane button option). Hook the button to your desired/custom terminal command.  This would effectively handle the use case where you want to run your app with Copilot diagnosing the errors in the terminal which happens like 100 times a day.
